Kural_Info.Tamil_Text: அறிவின்மை இன்மையுள் இன்மை பிறிதின்மை இன்மையா வையா துலகு.
Kural_Info.English_Meaning: The want of wisdom is the greatest of all wants; but that of wealth the world will not regard as such.

Layered_Composition.Foreground: Two figures stand before the personified World. The first figure represents the poverty of knowledge ('அறிவின்மை'). They are depicted as a hollow, empty silhouette, a true void.
Layered_Composition.Midground: The second figure represents the poverty of wealth ('பிறிதின்மை'). They are simply dressed in rags but are otherwise a solid, complete person. The World is shown looking at the hollow figure with great pity and concern, recognizing it as the ultimate poverty ('இன்மையுள் இன்மை').
Layered_Composition.Background: The World looks at the materially poor person with indifference, not considering their state to be true poverty ('இன்மையா வையாது'). The image defines true poverty as a lack of knowledge, not a lack of money.

Art_Direction.Subject_and_Action: The poverty of knowledge is the poverty of poverties. The world does not consider any other form of poverty to be true poverty.
Art_Direction.Symbolic_Motifs: The person without knowledge as a hollow void is the central metaphor for the 'poverty of poverties'. The World's differing reactions (pity vs. indifference) clarifies the hierarchy of poverty.
Art_Direction.Mood_and_Emotion: Defining, profound, a re-evaluation of poverty.
Art_Direction.Lighting_and_Color: A bleak, empty light surrounds the hollow figure. A neutral, mundane light is on the materially poor person. The personified World is majestic and discerning.

Technical_Cues.Camera: A wide shot showing the two types of poor people and the World's judgment upon them.
Technical_Cues.Lighting: Symbolic lighting to differentiate the two states of poverty.

Cultural_Anchors: Poverty of Knowledge ('அறிவின்மை') as the ultimate poverty
